intro: Centaurea ferdinandi, commonly known as Ferdinand's cornflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring blue to purple ray florets surrounding yellow disk florets. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. Centaurea ferdinandi thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and rocky habitats.
